description: From French souterrain, from sous (“under”) +‎ terrain (“ground”).

entries.meaning: (archaeology) An underground chamber or passage sometimes used as a store, especially one associated with Iron Age settlements.
examples: Now when my son saw that I separated them, he secretly built this souterrain and furnished it and transported to it victuals, even as thou seest; and, when I had gone out a-sporting, came here with his sister and hid from me.
